Superb. Thanks Ken.

Regarding the question right at the end about applying objective
search once near a good solution. If we take the maze example, I would
say that once we have one (or a few) solutions that get through the
maze, we can run objective search to find robots that are faster
and/or take more direct/efficient routes - because the paths followed
by the robots produced by novelty might tend to wander around a bit.

This reminds me of Geoff Hinton's view of back propagation in his
talks on deep learning (which I may have mentioned before). Back prop
is essentially gradient descent towards optimal connection weights,
but the error signal is so weaked after being propagated through only
a few layers, that the gradient is pretty much dwarfed by noise. Deep
learning solves the problem of finding weights in networks with many
layers and thus solves the problem of abstract recognition and
modelling. Once you have those weights you can run backprop to
optimise the solution - and it works well in that role even when
applied to nets with many layers.

So the original method that was the focus of much attention (backprop)
became a stepping stone to a much stronger method, but remained as an
optimisation to the new method. The basic goal and idea was there, but
the method is/was too direct in how it goes about finding the goal
states.

Colin
